title: 107_hr3920
content: The "Rancher Preservation Act" may require special provisions for the black-tailed prairie dog under the Endangered Species Act of 1973. The Secretary must use the best scientific and commercial data available to determine the status of the black-tailed prairie dog as an endangered or threatened species. This includes giving weight to empirical or peer-reviewed data and field observations. Data from landowners regarding the species' status must be accepted and acknowledged. The Secretary must use the best scientific and commercial data available to determine the status of the black-tailed prairie dog as an endangered or threatened species. Data from landowners regarding the species' status must be accepted and acknowledged for any determination made. The term 'action' refers to decisions regarding the black-tailed prairie dog's status as endangered or threatened, as well as its removal from any list. A 'qualified individual' is someone with expertise in biological sciences relevant to such decisions. The Secretary must appoint independent scientific reviewers with expertise in the black-tailed prairie dog or similar species, free from conflicts of interest, not involved in related petitions, and without financial interests opposing the decision. Recommendations will be sought from the National. The Secretary appoints independent scientific reviewers, recommended by the National Academy of Sciences, to review and report on the scientific information of proposed actions. Reviewers must be free from conflicts of interest and will be compensated for their work. The Secretary appoints independent scientific reviewers recommended by the National Academy of Sciences to evaluate proposed actions. Reviewers are compensated for their work and provide their opinion on relevant scientific information within 3 months. The Secretary considers the reviewers' recommendations in the final determination, including a summary of the independent scientific review results. The independent scientific reviewers appointed by the Secretary evaluate proposed actions and provide their opinions within 3 months. The final determination includes a summary of the review results and an explanation if the majority recommendation is not followed. The reviewers' report is made public for review before the comment period closes. Special requirements regarding black-tailed prairie dog are outlined in Sec. 13.
